messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 70 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Abstract

Paper Abstract: 

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 70 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 70"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Lusternik‚ÄìSchnirelmann category for simplicial complexes",
        "A subexponential size triangulation of R‚ÄãPnùëÖsuperscriptùëÉùëõRP^{n}",
        "Casson‚Äôs invariant for oriented homology 3-spheres, volume 36 of.",
        "A simple algorithm for homeomorphic surface reconstruction",
        "Efficient data structure for representing and simplifying simplicial complexes in high dimensions",
        "The quickhull algorithm for convex hulls",
        "Ripser: efficient computation of Vietoris‚ÄìRips persistence barcodes",
        "Twister (computer software)",
        "The homotopy type of the matroid Grassmannian",
        "Erratum to ‚Äúthe homotopy type of the matroid grassmannian‚Äù",
        "Geometric and topological inference, vol. 57",
        "Manifold reconstruction using tangential Delaunay complexes",
        "On the randomized construction of the Delaunay tree",
        "The Magma algebra system. I. The user language",
        "Geometric transforms for fast geometric algorithms",
        "Regina: Software for low-dimensional topology",
        "Topology and data",
        "Robust and efficient Delaunay triangulations of points on or close to a sphere",
        "An introduction to Topological Data Analysis: fundamental and practical aspects for data scientists",
        "A combinatorial formula for Stiefel-Whitney classes",
        "Simplicial structures and transverse cellularity",
        "Lusternik-Schnirelmann category",
        "SnapPy, a computer program for studying the geometry and topology of 333-manifolds",
        "The Delaunay hierarchy",
        "Topology preserving edge contraction",
        "Edge contractions and simplicial homology",
        "Edgewise subdivision of a simplex",
        "Topological persistence and simplification",
        "Triangulating topological spaces",
        "simpcomp - a GAP toolkit for simplicial complexes, Version 2.1.14",
        "Foundations of algebraic topology",
        "Topological complexity of motion planning",
        "List homomorphisms to reflexive graphs",
        "Lusternik‚ÄìSchnirelmann category of simplicial complexes and finite spaces",
        "Computing simplicial representatives of homotopy group elements",
        "On the LS-category and topological complexity of projective product spaces",
        "Effective topological degree computation based on interval arithmetic",
        "Configuration spaces, bistellar moves, and combinatorial formulae for the first pontryagin class",
        "A formula for Stiefel-Whitney homology classes",
        "A 15-vertex triangulation of the quaternionic projective plane",
        "How many simplices are needed to triangulate a Grassmannian?",
        "Estimating the discrete Lusternik-Schnirelmann category",
        "Gap ‚Äì groups, algorithms, and programming, version 4.11.1",
        "The efficiency of a homology algorithm based on discrete morse theory and coreductions",
        "Algebraic topology",
        "Approximate triangulations of Grassmann manifolds",
        "Combinatorial algebraic topology",
        "On special coverings of a finite-dimensional sphere",
        "Minimal triangulations of Kummer varieties",
        "M√©thodes topologiques dans les probl√®mes variationnels. premi√®re partie: Espaces √† un nombre fini de dimensions",
        "Triangulated manifolds with few vertices and vertex-transitive group actions",
        "Lectures on the triangulation conjecture",
        "The gudhi library: Simplicial complexes and persistent homology",
        "Characteristic classes.(am-76)",
        "CHomP - Computation Homology Project software",
        "Elements of algebraic topology",
        "Finding the homology of submanifolds with high confidence from random samples",
        "Persistence theory: from quiver representations to data analysis",
        "An algorithm computing homotopy groups",
        "Algorithm 772: Stripack: Delaunay triangulation and Voronoi diagram on the surface of a sphere",
        "Approximate and discrete euclidean vector bundles",
        "Triangulations of complex projective spaces",
        "Laguerre Voronoi diagram on the sphere",
        "The topology toolkit",
        "Recovering the homology of immersed manifolds",
        "Computing persistent Stiefel‚ÄìWhitney classes of line bundles",
        "Combinatorial homotopy. I.",
        "Simplicial spaces, nuclei and m-groups",
        "Relative simplicial approximation",
        "Computing persistent homology"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 70 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Abstract, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
